channel.title: Perl Weekly newsletter
channel.description: A free, once a week e-mail round-up of hand-picked news and articles about Perl.

item.title: For senior Perl developers looking to raise the stakes
item.description: An iconic London firm is looking for a Managing Perl Developer / Web Manager whoâ€™s got the same nose for success as they do. If youâ€™ve been leading a 2-3 person team, and itâ€™s time to step up to more responsibility on your way to a CTO role, this is an excellent opportunity.

item.title: Namaste and a Beach Day - Perl Position in California
item.description: Our client is looking for a Perl programmer who wants to tame the job jungle for employers and employees through their candidate sourcing and data management products. We know what youâ€™re thinking: When every day is a California postcard, who needs a vacation?

item.title: Modern Perl developers needed to drive medical diagnosis into the future
item.description: Itâ€™s incredible how diseases and illnesses that were once fatal can be so easily treated today. Medical progress ploughs forward, but it relies on technological breakthrough. Thatâ€™s where you and our client come in.

item.title: Do one thing, do it well, and do it with Perl (US)
item.description: The company has longevity as well, and thatâ€™s no accident â€“ they like what they do, and they do it well. Theyâ€™ve stuck with their core competency and forging considered and effective decisions across their history. If your ego requires something sexier, go try the Valley.

item.title: Remote Modern Perl, 2-3 month project, $50/hr
item.description: Do you have Modern Perl experience? Not afraid of Plack, DBIx::Class, and writing unit tests? Want to work from home, anywhere in the world, but donâ€™t mind targeting US working hours? We need a few stand-out developers to help with a client with a one-off project.

item.title: Infinite work is less work
item.description: Damian showing the power of Perl 6 by solving the task in the Perl Weekly Challenge. Highly Recommended.

item.title: Pizza Party for 100
item.description: Veesh first blog post for the Perl Weekly Challenge. Congratulations.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #16: Bitcoin Addresses
item.description: Laurent's blog about Bitcoin address task is again full of ideas. Read if you want to know more.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #16: Pythagoras Pie
item.description: Laurent's blog is always fun to read and takes up plenty of time to understand as it covers so many different aspects of the given task.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 016: Pythagoras Pie Puzzle and Bitcoin Address Validation
item.description: Choroba blog always taught me something new every week. This week, I tried to get my head around the graph. I specially enjoyed the discussion with regard to the Bitcoin address validation task. Must read, if you want to know the details.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge #016
item.description: Athanasius started the discussion from Perl5 perspective then slowly moved towards to Perl6. Well explained tasks.

item.title: Pythagoras Bitcoin with Perl 6
item.description: Arne is as usual sharp and crystal clear in his understanding and explanation. Ideal for someone new to the language.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge 016
item.description: I enjoyed the discussion of the task in the blog as it shows the thought process. Highly Recommended.

item.title: RECAP - Perl Weekly Challenge - 016
item.description: Review of last week challenge. There are plenty of great solutions.

item.title: Perl Weekly Challenge - 017
item.description: Don't miss the fun and try new challenges every week. For more information, please read FAQ page.

item.description: Putting an end to the turmoil.

item.title: Using generate_series and daterange for fun and profit
item.description: Domm shared interesting use case with real world example. I loved it.

item.title: A Technical Hiring Process Revisited
item.description: Dave shared some tenets of the Technical Hiring Process. A very interesting take.

item.title: Next stable DBD::SQLite will be released in the mid-August
item.description: Kenichi made big announcement about the next stable release of DBD::SQLite. I am looking forward to.

item.title: Get the most affordable premium labels for your business at StickerYou.com
item.description: Do you spend way too much on very average-looking labels? With StickerYou.com, you premium labels for an incredibly affordable cost! Order high-quality labels for your business, your family, your staff or your classroom. StickerYou.comâ€™s online editor allows you to customize them in an endless number of shapes and sizes in a matter of minutes. An there are no minimum order quantities! Better yet, use code PERL10 at checkout for 10% off!

item.title: #416 - The Perl Conference in Riga
item.description:
Hi there

As you all know the next big Perl event is happening in Riga, Latvia between 7th-9th August 2019. They even put together very entertaining introductory video. There are going to be 3 keynote speakers this time i.e. Larry Wall (Perl Keynote), Jonathan Worthington (Perl 6 Concurrency) and Elizabeth Mattijsen. I met Larry Wall first time last year during The Perl Conference in Glasgow. As I am attending the event all 3 days, it would be a great opportunity to meet him again and many other great people.

If you haven't bought the ticket then please don't delay any further and buy now. You can checkout the schedule to find out topics covered.

Last but not the least, Congratulation to all English fan for winning the first Cricket World Cup 2019. It was a thrilling and nail biting finish. New Zealand, you played well and deserve all the praise. I watched the final as neutral spectator as my Indian cricket team couldn't make it to the final. Never mind, there is always next time.

Have fun and enjoy reading this week newsletter.
